resources: BAIS V & TBPS ""P01. Starting with the head of household"", please give me names of all persons who spent the night with this household last night. ""Make sure to include: "\n 1. Usual members who did not spend the night but will be available in any of the next 5 days \n\n 2. Persons who were away last night on duty, prayer meetings, wake keeping, etc. \n\n 3. Babies, newly born, elderly, persons with disability who slept with this household. \n\n 4. Visitors " P02. What is # \'s relationship to * (Head of House)? PURPOSE OF THE SURVEY This survey will help us to know how many people in Botswana have HIV, how many people have TB and need health services. It will also tell us about people’s risk for getting HIV and TB. We plan to ask about 16 000 individuals to join this survey. If you participate, your taking part will help MoHW make health services better in the country. SURVEY PROCEDURES INTERVIEWS If you do participate in this survey, we will ask you questions about your demographics, past experience with HIV services, and your behavior. The interview will take about 45 minutes. BLOOD DRAW, TESTING, AND RETURNING OF RESULTS: We will ask you for consent to draw blood from you in order to conduct HIV testing and other laboratory based HIV-related tests. We will use a needle to take less than a teaspoon of your blood from your arm. If it’s not possible to take blood from your arm, then we will try to take a few drops of blood from your finger. If you need to know your results the testing and counseling session will be done here in your home and will take about 40 minutes. If you test positive for HIV, we will send your blood to a laboratory to measure the amount of HIV in your blood. This result will be available at the health facility of your choice within 8 to 10 weeks. You may or may not be selected for other additional tests related to HIV. If you are selected, some of your blood sample will be sent to other laboratories. If we have test results that might help guide your care or treatment, we will attempt to contact you to notify you when your results are ready for collection from a health facility of your choice. Your participation in the survey is voluntary and if you decide to participate, you may change your mind at any time and stop taking part. If you decide not to take part, it will not affect access to healthcare in any way. STORAGE OF SPECIMENS We would also ask for your permission to store your remaining blood in a specimen bank at the National Health Laboratory (NHL) for future research tests. These tests may be used for future research on HIV/AIDS and TB. This sample will be stored for five years. Your remaining blood will not be sold or used for commercial reasons. If you do not agree to long-term storage of your blood samples, we will destroy the samples after survey-related tests have been completed. Your participation in the survey is voluntary and if you decide to participate, you may change your mind at any time and stop taking part. If you decide not to take part, it will not affect your healthcare in any way. RISKS The risks of participation are minimal. We will do everything we can to keep your information confidential. You may feel uncomfortable about some of the questions we will ask and you may refuse to answer any question. If you take part, you will be offered free testing for HIV. BENEFITS Your participation in the survey will inform you of your HIV status. HIV positive patients will receive counseling and linkage to free care and treatment. The information you provide will also be used to improve the health of Batswana. Your responses will help us develop more effective programs to fight HIV and other diseases in Botswana. COSTS There is no cost to you for being part of the survey and you will not be paid for your participation. CONFIDENTIALITY What we talk about during the survey will be kept private, even from your family, and will not be shown to anyone outside of the survey team. Your answers to the questions will be identified only by a number and not by your name. Your name will not appear on any survey results that we share with MoHW, publishing or presented at scientific meetings. The information we collect during the survey will not be released outside of the survey groups listed unless there is an issue of safety. The following individuals and/or agencies will be able to look at your interview records to help oversee the conduct of this survey: 1. Staff members from Institutional Review Boards or Ethics Committees overseeing the conduct of this survey to ensure that we are protecting your rights as a person taking part in the survey. These include the Botswana Human Research Development Committee (HRDC), the Institutional Review Boards at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the WHO Task Force for TB. 2. Survey staff and monitors. Your permission to allow us to use and share your information with the groups above will expire five years after the end of the survey. If during or post the survey you want your information to be removed from the survey data, or have any questions about the survey, or feel that you have been harmed by taking part, you should contact the Botswana Human Research Development Committee (HRDC) and NACA, MoHW: Principal Investigator: Oaitse I Motsamai, MPH, DrPH, (NACA-Research Monitoring and Evaluation) Phone Number: +267-3710314. Fax Number: +267-3170960. Physical Address: Unit 9, Westgate Mall Western By-Pass Phase 2. Private Bag 00463 Gaborone Phone: +267 3654811 Email: oimotsamai@gmail.com If you have any questions about your rights as a participant in this survey, you can contact HRDC using the following addresses: Chairperson of Botswana Human Research Development Committee Plot 54609, Government Enclave Private Bag 0038, Gaborone www.moh.gov.bw At this time, do you want to ask me anything about: Your blood being taken in your home? Testing your blood in the laboratory? PERMISSION STATEMENT This consent form has been read out to you and you have been given a copy. Any questions that you had have been answered satisfactorily. You know that after choosing to participate in the survey, you may withdraw at any time if you so wish. You know that your participation is voluntary. You have been given sufficient time to consent. PURPOSE OF THE SURVEY This survey will help us to know how many people in Botswana have HIV, how many people have TB and need health services. It will also tell us about people’s risk for getting HIV and TB. We plan to ask about 38 000 individuals to join this survey. If you participate, your taking part will help MoHW make health services better in the country. SURVEY PROCEDURES If you join this survey, we will administer an individual questionnaire. We will, thereafter, invite you to the TB station, which is located in your area, to carry out Chest x-ray screening and sputum collection if you are illegible. If you have a symptom of TB and/or your CXR is abnormal, we will request that you submit 2 specimens of what comes out when you cough (sputum), one on the spot and another after 1 hour. These specimens will be sent to the National TB Reference Lab to test for TB. You will be offered HIV testing and counseling which will take about 45 minutes. You may agree to the interview without agreeing to give your blood or to test for TB and vice versa. INTERVIEWS If you do participate in this survey, we will ask you questions about your demographics, and your behavior. The interview will take about 45 minutes. CXR, SPUTUM COLLECTION, TESTING, AND RESULTS RETURN: We will ask you for consent for the TB screening which will involve a Chest x-ray (CXR) and 2 sputum sample collections if your symptoms and/or CXR indicate it is necessary. If you screen positive for TB symptoms, have an abnormal CXR, refuse CXR or symptom screening, or are unable to undergo a CXR then you are eligible for sputum collection. All participants with abnormal CXR will undergo HIV testing at the TB station if they had not tested at the household level. We will prick your finger to obtain a blood sample to use in an HIV rapid test. You will be referred to care if HIV positive. A medical officer will discuss your screening results, why you may have been chosen for sputum collection, next steps, and answer any questions you may have. If you test positive for TB in at least one of your sputum samples, we will send your CXR results and treatment history to a medical panel for review. Inconclusive cases may have sputum samples sent for culture. All case identified as TB during the survey will be linked to patient care. STORAGE OF XRAYS We would like to ask for your permission to store CXR data in duplicate for 2 years to allow for re-analysis in cases there are any queries to the survey results during this period, after which they will be destroyed. Your participation in the survey is voluntary and if you decide to participate, you may change your mind at any time and stop taking part. If you decide not to take part, it will not affect access to healthcare in any way. RISKS The risks of participation are minimal. We will do everything we can to keep your information confidential. You may feel uncomfortable about some of the questions we will ask and you may refuse to answer any question. If you take part, you will be offered free testing for TB and HIV. BENEFITS Your participation in the survey will inform you of your TB status. TB positive participants will be promptly started on treatment. The information you provide will also be used to improve the health of Batswana. Your responses will help us develop more effective programs to fight TB and other diseases in Botswana. COSTS There is no cost to you for being part of the survey and you will not be paid for your participation. CONFIDENTIALITY What we talk about during the survey will be kept private, even from your family, and will not be shown to anyone outside of the survey team. Your answers to the questions will be identified only by a number and not by your name. Your name will not appear on any survey results that we share with MoHW, publish or present at scientific meetings. The information we collect during the survey will not be released outside of the survey groups listed unless there is an issue of safety. The following individuals and/or agencies will be able to look at your interview records to help oversee the conduct of this survey: 1. Staff members from Institutional Review Boards or Ethics Committees overseeing the conduct of this survey to ensure that we are protecting your rights as a person taking part in the survey. These include the Botswana Human Research Development Committee (HRDC), the Institutional Review Boards at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the WHO Task Force for TB. 2. Survey staff and monitors. Your permission to allow us to use and share your information with the groups above will expire five years after the end of the survey. If during or post the survey you want your information to be removed from the survey data, or have any questions about the survey, or feel that you have been harmed by taking part, you should contact the Botswana Human Research Development Committee (HRDC) and NACA, MoHW: Principal Investigator: Oaitse I Motsamai, MPH, DrPH, (NACA-Research Monitoring and Evaluation) Phone Number: +267-3710314. Fax Number: +267-3170960. Physical Address: Unit 9, Westgate Mall Western By-Pass Phase 2. Private Bag 00463 Gaborone Phone: +267 3654811 Email: oimotsamai@gmail.com If you have any questions about your rights as a participant in this survey, you can contact HRDC using the following addresses: Chairperson of Botswana Human Research Development Committee Plot 54609, Government Enclave Private Bag 0038, Gaborone www.moh.gov.bw 00 Head 01 Spouse/Partner 02 Son/Daughter 03 Stepchild 04 Grandchild 05 Parent 06 Grandparent 07 Brother/Sister 08 Nephew/Niece 09 Son/Daughter-inlaw 10 Parent-in-law 11 Other relative 12 Not related P03. Do not know any Other Specify READ OUT:::::::::::: Now I am going to ask you some questions about facts and myths about TB and HIV. I would like you to answer the questions to the best of your knowledge....................................................... Q606. Is it possible for a healthy looking person to have HIV? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q607. Can people reduce their chances of getting HIV by using a condom correctly every time they have sex? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q608. Do you think that a person can get infected with HIV through mosquito bites? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q609. Can people reduce their chances of getting HIV by having only one UNINFECTED sex partner who has no other partners? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q610. Can a person get infected with HIV by sharing a meal (from the same plate) with a person who has HIV? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q611. Can HIV be transferred from a mother to a child: .........READ OUT Q611a. During pregnancy? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q611b. During delivery? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q611c. During breastfeeding? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q612. If a mother is infected with HIV, is there any way to avoid transmission during pregnancy? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q612a. If yes, what ways? 1. Antiretroviral therapy(Art, drugs after birth) 2. Caesarean section 9. Dont know Other Specify Q613. If a mother is infected with HIV, is there any way to avoid transmission to a new born baby? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q613a. If yes, what ways? 1. Antiretroviral therapy(Art, drugs after birth) 2. Not breastfeeding 3. Exclusive breastfeeding 9. Dont know Other Specify Q614. What do you believe anti-retroviral (ARVs) do? 1. Cure AIDS 2. Cure HIV 3. Suppress HIV 4. Boost Immune System 9. Dont know Other Specify Q615. Do you think that people on ARVs should always use condoms? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q616. In your opinion, who can be infected with TB? ............MULTIPLE RESPONSES ........NOT A READ OUT 1. Anybody 2. Poor people 3. Homeless people 4. Alcoholics 5. Drug users 6. People Living with HIV and AIDS 7. People who have been in Prison 8. Smokers 9. Dont know Other Specify Q617. Can a person get TB through......? Q617a. Sharing a meal with a person who has TB? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617b. Sharing clothes with a person who has TB? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617c. Sex with a woman who miscarried? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617d. Sex with a widow/widower? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617e. Born in a family with HIV? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617f. Born in a family with SEJESO? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617g. Touching items in public places? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617h. Being in contact with someone with TB? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q617i. Other specify? Other specify Q618. Do you think that TB can be treated/cured? 1. Yes 2. No 9. Dont know Q619. What are the signs and symptoms of TB? ............MULTIPLE RESPONSE.............NOT A READ OUT 1. Rash 2. Cough 3. Cough that lasts longer than 3 weeks 4. Coughing up blood 5. Severe headache 6.
